question:
Which of the following public sector enterprises falls under the status ‘Maharatna’?

SSC CPO 24/11/2020 (Evening)
option_1: Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited
option_2: Steel Authority of India Limited
option_3: Mahanagar Telephone Nigam Limited
option_4: Hindustan Aeronautics Limited
solution:
• Steel Authority of India Limited (SAIL) is one of the Maharatna public sector enterprises in India.
  • The Maharatna status is granted to CPSEs (Central Public Sector Enterprises) that meet specific criteria like net profit, turnover, and net worth, allowing them greater financial autonomy.
  • BSNL, MTNL, and HAL are either Miniratna or Navratna, but not Maharatna.
  • Maharatna companies can invest up to ₹5,000 crores in a project without government approval.

Additional Information:

  • Other Maharatna companies include ONGC, NTPC, IOCL, BHEL, and GAIL.
  • The Maharatna scheme was introduced by the Government of India in 2009 to improve the global competitiveness of top-performing PSUs.
  • SAIL is one of India’s largest steel producers and plays a key role in infrastructure and industrial development.

question:
Which of the following Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) seeks to ‘Protect, restore and promote sustainable use of terrestrial ecosystems, sustainably manage forests, combat desertification, and halt and reverse land degradation and halt biodiversity loss’?

SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Afternoon)
option_2: SDG 7
option_3: SDG 17
option_4: SDG 15
solution:
• SDG 15 (Sustainable Development Goal 15) aims to:

    “Protect, restore and promote sustainable use of terrestrial ecosystems, sustainably manage forests, combat desertification, and halt and reverse land degradation and halt biodiversity loss.”

  • This goal addresses issues related to deforestation, land degradation, desertification, and biodiversity conservation.
  • It promotes sustainable management of forests, halting the loss of natural habitats, and protecting endangered species.
  • Other SDGs:
    • SDG 12 – Responsible consumption and production
    • SDG 7 – Affordable and clean energy
    • SDG 17 – Partnerships for the goals

Additional Information:

  • The United Nations adopted 17 SDGs in 2015 as part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.
  • India's efforts towards SDG 15 include initiatives like CAMPA, National Afforestation Programme, and Project Tiger.
  • SDG 15 targets include halting biodiversity loss by 2030 and integrating ecosystem values into development planning.

question:
The UN’s Sustainable Development Goal 6 aims to ____________ .

SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Evening)
option_1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
option_2: Ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all
option_3: End poverty in all forms everywhere
option_4: Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impact
solution:
• Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 6 of the United Nations aims to:

    “Ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all.”

  • This goal focuses on providing safe and affordable drinking water, improving water quality, and expanding access to adequate sanitation and hygiene.
  • It also promotes efficient water use, protection of water-related ecosystems, and support for community water management.
  • Other SDGs mentioned:
    • SDG 3 – Ensure healthy lives and well-being for all (Option a)
    • SDG 1 – End poverty in all forms (Option c)
    • SDG 13 – Combat climate change and its impacts (Option d)

Additional Information:

  • India’s initiatives aligned with SDG 6 include Jal Jeevan Mission, Swachh Bharat Abhiyan, and Namami Gange Programme.
  • Globally, SDG 6 aims to achieve universal access to clean water and sanitation by 2030.
  • It also addresses challenges like open defecation, polluted water bodies, and inequity in water distribution.

question:
With reference to the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals, which of the following is the SDG 10?

SSC CPO 24/11/2020 (Morning)
option_2: Reduced inequalities
option_3: Zero hunger
option_4: Decent work and economic growth
solution:
• Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 10 aims to “Reduce inequality within and among countries.”
  • It addresses economic, social, and political inequality and promotes inclusive policies for all, especially for the poor, marginalized, and vulnerable.
  • This includes reducing income disparities, ensuring equal opportunities, and enhancing representation for developing countries in global institutions.
  • Other options refer to:
    • SDG 13 – Climate action (Option a)
    • SDG 2 – Zero hunger (Option c)
    • SDG 8 – Decent work and economic growth (Option d)

Additional Information:

  • SDG 10 promotes safe migration, equal access to resources, and social protection policies.
  • It encourages reforms in global financial systems, including IMF and WTO, to better reflect the interests of developing countries.
  • India’s efforts include reservation policies, financial inclusion schemes, and welfare programs aimed at reducing inequality.

question:
In the context of UN Sustainable Development Goals, which of the following pairs is INCORRECT?

SSC CGL 07/03/2020 (Evening)
option_2: Decent Work and Economic Growth – SDG 8
option_3: No Poverty – SDG 1
option_4: Quality Education – SDG 3
solution:
• The incorrect pair is (d) Quality Education – SDG 3.
  • Quality Education is actually SDG 4, not SDG 3.
  • SDG 3 refers to Good Health and Well-being, which focuses on reducing mortality, improving health services, and combating diseases.
  • The following pairs are correct:
    • Zero Hunger – SDG 2
    • Decent Work and Economic Growth – SDG 8
    • No Poverty – SDG 1

Additional Information:

  • SDG 4 aims to “Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all.”
  • There are 17 SDGs in total, adopted by the United Nations in 2015 as part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.
  • India has implemented several programs like Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan and National Education Policy 2020 to align with SDG 4.

question:
The first industrial policy of independent India was announced in-

UPUDA/LDA (Mains), 2010
option_2: (b) 1948
option_3: (c) 1950
option_4: (d) 1956
solution:
• The first Industrial Policy of independent India was announced in the year 1948, known as the Industrial Policy Resolution of 1948.
  • This policy laid the foundation of a mixed economy, where both the public and private sectors were assigned roles in industrial development.
  • It emphasized the importance of state control in strategic sectors, while allowing private enterprise in other areas.
  • The Industrial Policy of 1956 later expanded on this framework and is often considered the core policy for India's industrial development in the Nehruvian era.

Additional Information:

  • The 1948 policy categorized industries into:
    • Exclusive state monopoly
    • State regulation with private participation
    • Private sector under state control
  • It was aligned with the Directive Principles of State Policy and aimed at achieving a socialist pattern of society.
  • The Planning Commission played a key role in coordinating industrial development under this policy.

question:
In which Industrial Policy Resolution the idea of ​​'Joint Sector' for industrial development in India was put forward?

UPPSC (Mains), 2004
option_1: In the Industrial Policy of 1948
option_2: In the Industrial Policy of 1956
option_3: In the Industrial Policy of 1980
option_4: In the Industrial Policy of 1991
solution:
• The concept of ‘Joint Sector’—a collaboration between public and private sectors—was first introduced in the Industrial Policy Resolution of 1956.
  • This policy was guided by the vision of a socialist pattern of society, and aimed to strike a balance between state control and private participation in key industries.
  • In the Joint Sector, both government and private investors would hold equity, but management and strategic control would remain with the government.
  • This model was intended to mobilize private capital while keeping the public interest safeguarded.

Additional Information:

  • The 1956 policy classified industries into three schedules:
    • Schedule A – Exclusive responsibility of the State (e.g. arms, atomic energy)
    • Schedule B – State would set up industries, but private sector allowed to supplement
    • Schedule C – Remaining industries open to private sector
  • The idea of Joint Sector was seen as a middle path to balance growth with social equity.
  • Notable examples of Joint Sector enterprises include Maruti Udyog Ltd. (initially) and Oil India Ltd. in its early years.

question:
The new economic policy of liberalization, privatization and globalization was announced, Prime Minister-

UPPSC (Pre), 2013
option_2: By Vishwanath Pratap Singh
option_3: By Narasimha Rao
option_4: By Atal Bihari Vajpayee
solution:
• The New Economic Policy (NEP) of Liberalization, Privatization, and Globalization (LPG) was introduced in 1991 under the leadership of Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao.
  • The Finance Minister at that time was Dr. Manmohan Singh, who played a pivotal role in designing and implementing the reforms.
  • The policy aimed to open up the Indian economy, reduce government control, attract foreign investment, and integrate India with the global market.
  • The other options are incorrect:
    • Rajiv Gandhi initiated early computerization and efficiency reforms but not the LPG policy.
    • V.P. Singh focused more on social justice and the Mandal Commission.
    • Atal Bihari Vajpayee further deepened reforms later, but he did not initiate the 1991 policy.

Additional Information:

  • The 1991 reforms were introduced in response to a severe economic crisis, including low foreign exchange reserves, high inflation, and fiscal deficit.
  • The policy reduced licensing requirements, encouraged private sector participation, and devalued the rupee to boost exports.
  • It marked the end of the license-permit-quota Raj and the beginning of a market-driven economy.

question:
Which of the following commodity groups is not included in FMCG (Fast Moving Consumer Goods)?

UPPSC (Mains), 2012
option_2: Cosmetics (shampoo and soap)
option_3: Dairy products (milk and cheese)
option_4: Bakery products (biscuits and bread)
solution:
• FMCG (Fast Moving Consumer Goods) are products that are sold quickly and at relatively low cost, often used on a daily basis.
  • Categories typically included in FMCG are:
    • Cosmetics and toiletries (e.g., shampoo, soap)
    • Dairy products (e.g., milk, cheese)
    • Bakery products (e.g., bread, biscuits)
  • Automobiles (like cars and motorcycles) are durable goods, not consumed quickly or regularly, and are not part of the FMCG category.

Additional Information:

  • FMCG products have a short shelf life, high turnover, and are sold in large quantities.
  • Examples of FMCG brands include Amul, Britannia, Colgate, HUL, Nestlé, etc.
  • FMCG is one of the largest sectors in India, contributing significantly to retail sales and employment.

Match List-1 and List-11 and select the correct answer from the code given below:

List-IList-II

B. Bokaro2. Jharkhand

C. Durgapur3. Odisha

IAS, 2005; UPUDA/LDA (Pre), 2001

solution:

question:
The objective of the Mudra scheme of the Government of India is-

RAS/RTS, 2013
option_1: Providing easy financial assistance for setting up small businesses
option_2: Taking initiatives to improve currency management
option_3: Providing loans to poor farmers
option_4: Complementing the Jan Dhan Yojana
solution:
• The MUDRA Scheme (Micro Units Development and Refinance Agency) was launched by the Government of India in 2015 with the main aim of providing financial assistance to small and micro enterprises.
  • It enables non-corporate, non-farm small/micro enterprises to access loans up to ₹10 lakh without collateral.
  • The scheme promotes entrepreneurship, self-employment, and inclusive growth, especially in the informal sector.
  • Other options:
    • (b) – Related to RBI and not the goal of MUDRA.
    • (c) – Loan to poor farmers is covered under other schemes like Kisan Credit Card.
    • (d) – While MUDRA complements Jan Dhan indirectly, it is not its primary objective.

Additional Information:

  • MUDRA loans are categorized into three products:
    • Shishu (up to ₹50,000)
    • Kishore (₹50,001 to ₹5 lakh)
    • Tarun (₹5 lakh to ₹10 lakh)
  • These loans are provided through banks, MFIs, NBFCs, and other financial institutions.
  • MUDRA supports a wide range of sectors like trading, manufacturing, services, artisans, and food processing.

question:
'Kandla' situated in the Gulf of Kutch is famous for which of the following?

UPPSC (Mains), 2013
option_2: Diamond cutting and polishing
option_3: Export processing zone
option_4: Traditional arts and crafts centre
solution:
• Kandla, located in the Gulf of Kutch in Gujarat, is well known for hosting one of India's first Export Processing Zones (EPZs), established in 1965.
  • It was developed to promote export-oriented industrial growth, offering infrastructure, tax benefits, and simplified procedures to exporters.
  • This made Kandla a significant hub for international trade and export promotion.
  • Other options:
    • Ship breaking industry is primarily associated with Alang, not Kandla.
    • Diamond cutting and polishing is famous in Surat, Gujarat.
    • Traditional arts and crafts are more prominent in places like Kutch, but not specifically Kandla.

Additional Information:

  • Kandla Port (now Deendayal Port) is one of the major ports of India, handling large volumes of cargo and petroleum products.
  • The EPZ at Kandla was later converted into a Special Economic Zone (SEZ), continuing to attract foreign and domestic investment.
  • The port and SEZ together make Kandla a strategic trade and logistics center on India’s western coast.

question:
Which of the following has been given the most importance in the 'Index of Eight Basic Industries'?

IAS, 2015
option_2: Electricity production
option_3: Fertilizer production
option_4: Steel production
solution:
• The Index of Eight Core Industries (ICI) is a monthly index published by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry to track the performance of eight major industrial sectors.
  • Among these, Electricity production holds the highest weight in the index — 85% (as per the base year 2011–12).
  • It is considered a key indicator of industrial and economic activity, as electricity is essential for all production processes.
  • Weightage comparison (base year 2011–12):
    • Electricity – 19.85%
    • Steel – 17.92%
    • Refinery products – 28.04% (highest individually but not listed in options)
    • Coal – 10.33%
    • Fertilizers – 2.63%

Additional Information:

  • The Eight Core Industries are:
    1. Coal
    2. Crude Oil
    3. Natural Gas
    4. Refinery Products
    5. Fertilizers
    6. Steel
    7. Cement
    8. Electricity
  • These industries constitute about 40.27% of the weight of items in the Index of Industrial Production (IIP).
  • Performance of these sectors is a crucial indicator of overall economic health.

question:
Which of the following is a problem of small scale industries?

UPPSC (Pre), 1991
option_2: Lack of marketing information
option_3: Lack of raw materials
option_4: All of the above
solution:
• Small Scale Industries (SSIs) in India face multiple challenges that hinder their growth and competitiveness.
  • These problems include:
    • Lack of capital: SSIs often struggle to access formal credit from banks due to absence of collateral and high interest rates.
    • Lack of marketing information: Most small industries lack access to market trends, demand forecasting, and distribution networks, making it difficult to compete with larger firms.
    • Lack of raw materials: SSIs face irregular supply and high cost of raw materials, affecting production and profitability.
  • Hence, all of the above are valid and interconnected problems of SSIs.

Additional Information:

  • Other common problems include technological obsolescence, skilled labor shortages, and regulatory hurdles.
  • Government initiatives like MSME Development Act (2006), Credit Guarantee Fund Scheme, and UDYAM Registration aim to support SSIs.
  • SSIs play a vital role in employment generation and regional development in India.

question:
The oldest large industry of India is-

UKPSC, 2002
option_2: Iron and steel
option_3: Jute
option_4: Paper
solution:
• The oldest large-scale industry in India is the cotton textile industry.
  • The first modern cotton textile mill was established in Mumbai (then Bombay) in 1854.
  • The industry grew rapidly due to availability of raw cotton, cheap labor, and port facilities in western India.
  • This makes cotton cloth (textile) industry the first organized and largest industrial sector of modern India.
  • Other options:
    • Jute industry began later, with the first mill set up in Rishra (near Kolkata) in 1855.
    • Iron and steel industry started with TISCO in Jamshedpur in 1907.
    • Paper industry also developed later and was not as dominant initially.

Additional Information:

  • The cotton industry played a pioneering role in India’s industrial development, especially during the British colonial period.
  • It contributed to urbanization, particularly in cities like Mumbai, Ahmedabad, and Surat.
  • The cotton industry was also central to India’s freedom movement, as seen in the Swadeshi movement.

question:
The industry for which Nepanaganar is known is-

UPPSC (Pre), 2001
option_2: Fertilizer
option_3: Handloom
option_4: News paper
solution:
• Nepanagar, located in Burhanpur district of Madhya Pradesh, is famous for its newsprint paper industry.
  • It is home to the Nepa Limited, which was India’s first newsprint manufacturing company, established in 1956.
  • The town developed around this industry and is often referred to as "Newsprint City" of India.
  • Other options:
    • Cement industry is more prominent in states like Rajasthan and Andhra Pradesh.
    • Fertilizer industry is concentrated in places like Sindri, Gorakhpur, and Namrup.
    • Handloom industry is famous in regions like Varanasi, Bhagalpur, and Chanderi.

Additional Information:

  • NEPA Ltd. is a public sector undertaking and was once the sole producer of newsprint in India.
  • The raw material used is wood pulp and waste paper, and the product is supplied to various newspaper publishing houses.
  • Although the industry faced modernization challenges, efforts have been made to revive and upgrade the plant.

question:
The combined weight of the index of eight core industries in the gross industrial production index in India is 37.90 per cent. Which of the following industries are included in those eight core industries?

Cement

2. Fertilizers

3. Natural Gas

4. Refinery Products

5. Textiles

Select the correct answer using the codes given below:

IAS, 2012
option_1: (a) Only 1 and 5
option_2: (b) Only 2,3 and 4
option_3: (c) Only 1,2,3 and 4
option_4: (d) 1,2,3,4 and 5
solution:
• The Index of Eight Core Industries (ICI) represents the performance of eight key sectors that form the foundation of India's industrial economy.
  • These eight industries contribute a combined weight of 40.27% (earlier 37.90%) to the Index of Industrial Production (IIP).
  • The correct eight core industries are:
    1. Coal
    2. Crude Oil
    3. Natural Gas
    4. Refinery Products
    5. Fertilizers
    6. Steel
    7. Cement
    8. Electricity
  • Among the options listed in the question:
    • Cement – Yes (Included)
    • Fertilizers – Yes (Included)
    • Natural Gas – Yes (Included)
    • Refinery Products – Yes (Included)
    • Textiles – No (Not part of eight core industries)

Correct answer: (c) Only 1,2,3 and 4

Additional Information:

  • The Index of Eight Core Industries is published monthly by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry.
  • The Refinery Products sector has the highest weight among the eight industries.
  • These sectors are used to gauge the economic and industrial activity in the country.

question:
Which of the following has/have happened in India after the liberalisation of economic policies in 1991?

The share of agriculture in GDP increased substantially.

2. The share of India's exports in world trade increased.

3. The inflow of FDI increased.

4. India's foreign exchange reserves increased substantially.

Select the correct answer using the code given below:

IAS, 2017
option_1: (a) Only 1 and 4
option_2: (b) Only 2, 3 and 4
option_3: (c) Only 2 and 3
option_4: (d) 1,2,3 and 4
solution:
Let’s evaluate each statement one by one:

  1. The share of agriculture in GDP increased substantially
    • Incorrect
    • After 1991, India's economy gradually shifted towards services and industry sectors.
    • The agriculture share in GDP declined, although it still employs a large population.
  2. The share of India's exports in world trade increased
    • Correct
    • Economic liberalisation led to reduced trade barriers, resulting in increased export competitiveness.
    • India's share in global exports has improved since 1991.
  3. The inflow of FDI increased
    • Correct
    • One of the key aims of liberalisation was to attract foreign investment.
    • FDI inflows have increased significantly across sectors like telecom, manufacturing, and services.
  4. India's foreign exchange reserves increased substantially
    • Correct
    • In 1991, India had a foreign exchange crisis. Post-liberalisation, due to increased exports, FDI, and remittances, forex reserves saw substantial growth.

Correct Answer: (b) Only 2, 3 and 4

question:
How many industries were listed in Schedule A of Industrial Policy, 1956?

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (Ist shift)
option_2: 17
option_3: 10
option_4: 12
solution:
• Schedule A of the Industrial Policy Resolution of 1956 listed industries that were to be exclusively owned or controlled by the State.
  • These were considered of strategic importance, such as arms, atomic energy, railways, etc.
  • The policy aimed at establishing a socialist pattern of society by expanding the role of the public sector.
  • A total of 17 industries were placed under Schedule A, reserved for the central government either fully or partly.
  • This classification was meant to strengthen state control over key and core sectors.

Additional Information:

  • Schedule B included 12 industries, where both public and private sectors could operate, but the State would take initiative.
  • Schedule C comprised the remaining industries, left to the private sector, but under State regulation.
  • The 1956 Policy emphasized rapid industrialization, reducing income inequality, and promoting regional balance.

question:
Industries are classified into ____________ categories in the Industrial Policy Resolution.

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (3rd shift)
option_2: Four
option_3: Three
option_4: Two
solution:
• The Industrial Policy Resolution of 1956 classified industries into three categories to define the role of the public and private sectors.
  • These categories were:
    • Schedule A: 17 industries exclusively under State control.
    • Schedule B: 12 industries where State would progressively take ownership, but private sector could operate.
    • Schedule C: All remaining industries, open to private sector participation under government regulation.
  • This three-fold classification was aimed at promoting a mixed economy with strong public sector leadership.

Additional Information:

  • This classification helped in prioritizing strategic industries, ensuring planned industrial growth.
  • It reinforced the socialist objective of the Indian government post-independence.
  • It provided a clear framework for industrial licensing and state participation.

question:
Small scale units are differentiated from large scale units on the basis of:

SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (3rd shift)
option_1: The size of unit area
option_2: The volume of sales
option_3: The volume of output
option_4: The amount of investment
solution:
• The main criterion to differentiate Small Scale Industries (SSIs) from large-scale units is the amount of investment in plant and machinery.
  • As per MSME (Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises) classification:
    • A small enterprise is defined by a fixed investment limit, which has changed over time.
  • Earlier, investment limits were fixed to encourage low capital-based, employment-generating units.
  • Factors like sales, output, or area are not used as primary parameters in official classification.

Additional Information:

  • The MSME Development Act, 2006 provides legal definitions and classifications.
  • In 2020, the Indian government revised MSME classification to include both investment and turnover criteria.
  • Small-scale industries contribute significantly to employment generation, exports, and regional development.

question:
What does the letter ‘M’ stand for in the MRTP Act 1969?

SSC CGL 02/12/2022 (1st shift)
option_2: Monopolies
option_3: Multi
option_4: Monopoly
solution:
• The MRTP Act, 1969 stands for Monopolies and Restrictive Trade Practices Act.
  • In this, the letter ‘M’ stands for Monopolies.
  • The Act was introduced to prevent concentration of economic power, and to prohibit monopolistic, restrictive, and unfair trade practices.
  • It aimed to protect consumer interests and ensure fair competition in the market.
  • The Act became ineffective after the introduction of the Competition Act, 2002, which replaced it in 2009.

Additional Information:

  • The MRTP Commission was set up under this Act to investigate and take action against anti-competitive practices.
  • The Act was inspired by global antitrust laws, especially those in the United States.
  • After liberalisation in 1991, the MRTP Act was found outdated and eventually repealed.

question: What was the main objective of the Industrial Policy Resolution of 1956 in India?
option_1: To promote only private sector growth
option_2: To eliminate public sector enterprises
option_3: To establish a socialistic pattern of society through mixed economy
option_4: To privatize basic industries
solution:
• The Industrial Policy Resolution of 1956 was a landmark in shaping India’s economic framework.
  • Its main objective was to establish a socialistic pattern of society, ensuring equity, social justice, and balanced economic development.
  • It aimed to build a mixed economy where public and private sectors co-exist, but with the public sector playing a dominant role.
  • The policy emphasized state control over key industries, especially those listed in Schedule A.
  • It reflected the Nehruvian vision of combining economic planning with social welfare.

Additional Information:

  • Encouraged rapid industrialization, especially in heavy industries.
  • Promoted regional balance by spreading industries across backward areas.
  • Supported small-scale industries to generate employment and reduce poverty.

question: Which of the following sectors was reserved exclusively for the public sector under early industrial policies?
option_2: Agricultural tools
option_3: Arms and ammunition production
option_4: Handicrafts and cottage industries
solution:
• Under the Industrial Policy Resolution of 1956, certain sectors were reserved exclusively for the public sector due to their strategic and national importance.
  • Arms and ammunition production was one such sector, placed in Schedule A, which was meant only for government ownership and operation.
  • These industries were considered critical for national security, hence not open to private enterprises.
  • The focus was to ensure state control over defense-related production and infrastructure.

Additional Information:

  • Other examples in Schedule A included atomic energy, railway transport, and defense equipment.
  • Consumer electronics and agricultural tools were not exclusive to the public sector.
  • Handicrafts and cottage industries remained largely in the private/unorganised sector and were promoted for employment generation.

question: The liberalization policy initiated in 1991 aimed at:
option_1: Increasing government control over industries
option_2: Nationalizing private industries
option_3: Reducing government interference and encouraging private enterprise
option_4: Closing foreign trade completely
solution:
• The Liberalization Policy of 1991 was a major reform under the New Economic Policy introduced by the Indian government to address the balance of payments crisis.
  • Its primary objective was to reduce government control over the economy and promote private sector participation.
  • The policy included abolition of industrial licensing, easing of FDI norms, and deregulation of markets.
  • It marked a shift from a controlled, planned economy to a more market-driven economic system.

Additional Information:

  • Introduced under Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao and Finance Minister Dr. Manmohan Singh.
  • Led to privatization, globalization, and a significant increase in foreign investment.
  • Paved the way for India’s integration into the global economy.

question: Which of the following is not a feature of the New Industrial Policy of 1991?
option_1: Abolition of industrial licensing
option_2: Promotion of foreign direct investment (FDI)
option_3: Expansion of public sector in all industries
option_4: Encouragement to private sector participation
solution:
• The New Industrial Policy of 1991 aimed to liberalize the Indian economy and move away from excessive government control.
  • It emphasized abolition of industrial licensing, promotion of foreign direct investment (FDI), and greater role for the private sector.
  • Contrary to option (c), the policy actually focused on reducing the role of the public sector, especially in non-strategic industries.
  • Hence, expansion of public sector was not a feature; rather, disinvestment and restructuring of public enterprises was encouraged.

Additional Information:

  • The number of industries reserved for the public sector was reduced from 17 to 8, and later to 3.
  • The policy marked a clear shift toward market-driven growth and integration with the global economy.
  • It also included financial sector reforms, tax reforms, and trade liberalization.

question: How did industrial reforms after 1991 impact the Indian economy?
option_1: Decline in industrial productivity
option_2: Increased competition and technological advancement
option_3: Closure of all public sector units
option_4: Complete ban on foreign trade
solution:
• The industrial reforms after 1991 were part of India's liberalization, privatization, and globalization (LPG) strategy.
  • These reforms led to increased competition, encouraging industries to improve productivity and efficiency.
  • With the easing of regulations and greater FDI inflows, Indian industries adopted modern technologies and improved their global competitiveness.
  • Hence, the correct impact was increased competition and technological advancement, not decline or closures.

Additional Information:

  • Industrial growth accelerated due to removal of licensing, reduced import tariffs, and market-driven policies.
  • Many public sector units were restructured, but not all were closed.
  • Foreign trade expanded, not banned, with India's integration into the global economy.

question: Which institution regulates and monitors industrial development in India after liberalization?
option_2: Reserve Bank of India
option_3: Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT)
option_4: Election Commission
solution:
• After the liberalization reforms of 1991, the responsibility for regulating and monitoring industrial development shifted to more specialized bodies.
  • The Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT), under the Ministry of Commerce and Industry, became the key institution for promoting industrial growth.
  • DPIIT handles formulation of industrial policies, FDI promotion, ease of doing business, and startup regulation.
  • It replaced earlier broader planning bodies in this specific domain.

Additional Information:

  • The Planning Commission was dissolved in 2014 and replaced by NITI Aayog.
  • The RBI regulates monetary policy and banks, not industrial development.
  • The Election Commission is unrelated to economic policy—it oversees free and fair elections.

question: Which of the following factors hindered industrial development in India before 1991?
option_1: Competition from private sector
option_2: Liberal economic policies
option_3: Excessive licensing and bureaucratic delays
option_4: Free market economy
solution:
• Before 1991, India's industrial development was hindered by the License Raj, where businesses had to obtain numerous licenses and approvals to start or expand operations.
  • This created bureaucratic delays, red tape, and often led to corruption and inefficiency.
  • The rigid regulatory framework discouraged entrepreneurship and private sector growth.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is excessive licensing and bureaucratic delays, not liberal policies or free markets, which were introduced only after 1991.

Additional Information:

  • The economy followed a planned model with the government playing a dominant role.
  • Industrial growth was limited to sectors approved by the state.
  • The New Industrial Policy of 1991 aimed to remove these barriers through liberalization and deregulation.

question: What was one of the major consequences of the license-permit-quota system in Indian industry?
option_1: Increase in efficiency and innovation
option_2: Faster approvals for new businesses
option_3: Bureaucratic control and slow industrial growth
option_4: Higher exports and global competitiveness
solution:
• The license-permit-quota system, also known as License Raj, was a major feature of Indian industry before 1991.
  • It required industrialists to obtain multiple licenses, permits, and quotas for production, expansion, and resource allocation.
  • This led to bureaucratic control, delays, and inefficient allocation of resources.
  • As a result, it caused slow industrial growth and discouraged entrepreneurial activity.

Additional Information:

  • The system fostered rent-seeking behavior, where businesses focused more on getting approvals than on innovation.
  • There was limited competition, which reduced productivity and technological progress.
  • The 1991 Industrial Policy aimed to dismantle this system through liberalization and deregulation.
